Comment: A federal judge just ruled that Trump can't cut off federal funding to sanctuary cities. The judge, William Orrick, said the administration doesn't have the power to punish cities that don't fully cooperate with immigration enforcement. Only Congress can attach strings to federal money — not the President.  This decision is a big win for places like San Francisco and Seattle, which were at risk of losing billions in federal funding. These cities argued that pulling funds would hurt public safety and damage trust in local law enforcement.  It’s not the first time Trump has run into legal trouble over immigration policies, and it probably won’t be the last. The administration says it’s still focused on putting Americans first — but this ruling puts a serious roadblock in their plans.

Comment: The loss of legitimacy is in the eyes of each person affected by each Republican action. It doesn't happen all at once. It happens when you read an article about a judge getting arrested or a child taken away. It happens when you see ICE kidnap someone.  Right now we see groups of citizens sometimes resisting authorities. Eventually that changes to violence. Things will just get harder and harder for Republican's to enact their policies as more people are repelled by the legal violations of the Trump administration.  Sure it would be nice if we all just suddenly decided we had enough and tossed Trump out. But that opportunity was in November, we decided we wanted to do it in hard mode instead.
Author: findingmike

Comment: [The 5th was pretty sizable.](https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-protest-calls-on-trump-musk-to-keep-hands-off-programs/) the 19th, I think there were a few neighborhood- and town-specific events, but the one I swung by at Central CC looked like a couple hundred (hey, better than nothing!) around 2pm or so. Didn't really seem as heavily advertised by flyers and the like around town.  I know the last few years there's been some pretty huge May 1 turnout during the various daytime rallies, and the evenings have been pretty peaceful. Here's hoping we continue that.
